title: I am in divorce. my wife, her attorney, her realtor are all working to flip my home. can i file ch 7 to stop a 1/28/19 auction?
question: div filed 04/23/15. i have been through excessive litigation, kids used to control me and limit custody unfairly. my mom helped us with a 100k gift of equity +27.5k my deposit & 5 k f/ wife on 5/22/14 to buy fam res. she 1st mentioned div 01/28/15 said no more till i was served 8.4.15. she abandon our home 7.19.15 and ceased support. i have lost 2 careers due to repeat TROs and loss of child visitations, but never custody. the last attack was 01/10/18 our kids didn't see dad for 3 months. 5 day hearing judge said had nothing to do with kids, but 6 month R.O on me to her + ang mgmt 16hrs bc emot. strss claim. RO dis. 9.28.18, but affected ability to work. i couldn' pay attorney he subd out 9.10 after 35k paid over 4yrs. ive lost 8 court appearances since. i agreed to appraise and sell home bc lost my emplmt bc TRO 01/18, fin hrdship & nonpmt. 02.22.18 stips agreed by all. hm appraised 775k 03/18. she refused my lstg 5/18 @ 829k, 7/18 775k, 9/18 775k new realtor. she filed 9/13 won cntrl of my childhood home & force me out of my prim res. Her agent lied to me w/ plan to assit, monopolized sale declin higher offers w/o discl. steered his buyr 680k,37kCC+100-140k remdl postsale his co.
answers:
To the extent that a proceeding under the bankruptcy laws is commenced, a bankruptcy estate is created, which includes all property in which the debtor has an interest, including 100% of all community property.

The automatic stay that arises upon the filing of the bankruptcy case will temporarily stay all proceedings against the debtor and property of the estate, although the exceptions to the automatic stay for family law and domestic relations proceedings are numerous and generally permit family law litigation to go forward. If the property which is to be sold pursuant to orders of the Family Court becomes property of the bankruptcy estate, the non-filing spouse can seek an order from the bankruptcy court modifying or lifting the automatic stay so as to allow the family law case to go forward.

Bankruptcy judges are loath to interfere with family law proceedings, which are in uniquely relegated to state courts. But if enforcement of the family law court orders for sale of marital property would interfere with the rights of creditors of the bankruptcy estate who would potentially be paid a dividend from the estate as result of administration by liquidation of estate assets, then they will be stayed, and only the issues not affecting the bankruptcy estate, i.e., child and spousal's support, domestic violence, support enforcement, etc., will be allowed to proceed.

Bear in mind that most claims arising from family law litigation, whether they be for or in the nature of support, or debts that may end up owing to your estranged and soon to be former wife are not dischargeable in bankruptcy. Chapter 13 alone can discharge marital debts, although debts for or in the nature of support are nondischargeable in all bankruptcy proceedings.

A bankruptcy will stop the scheduled sale. It won't necessarily prevent the property's ultimate sale. Critical questions include the property's equity and claims your ex-wife may have against you. See a local bankruptcy lawyer for guidance

All I can do is point out the obvious (which you most likely already have concluded):
1. Filing a Chapter 13 Case will stop the sale of the home; but only for an extremely limited time, until your ex-wife gets another hearing before either the Bankruptcy or Divorce Court, then it will proceed. My best estimate would be probably less than a month reprieve.

2. You need qualified legal assistance by an experienced Attorney in both the Divorce matter and the Bankruptcy Matter. You have recognized how quickly things turn on you when you don't have an Attorney in complex legal matters such as you have described.

3. You home is in jeopardy. You must take all steps available to you to protect your interest in the same. The best way to do so is to have proper legal representation.

4. There are no easy answers as to how you compensate your Attorneys when you have no income.

5. Talk to a qualified Bankruptcy Attorney immediately to discuss your various options. It may actually be that a Chapter 7 would result in a Chapter 7 Trustee selling the home for full market value which could render you more return than what your ex-wife and her realtor are proposing right now. Of course, without having all the details about what is owed on the home, determining equity cushion, etc. it can not be determined if a Chapter 7 Trustee would even want to get involved in the lingering domestic disputes that are associated with the home. But, you should take advantage of meeting with a qualified Bankruptcy Attorney to evaluate the situation immediately.

I wish you the best of luck in bringing closure to all of the legal issues you currently have in your life.
A bankruptcy filing will stop the auction. Seems like you have a lot of issues going on. Speak with a family attorney and bankruptcy attorney (or find one that practices both).

A bankruptcy will stop the auction of the real property at least until the other side gets a hearing in the BK court. That may happen fairly quickly.
You need an attorney to help you with the family law problems.
You also need an attorney to help with the bankruptcy.
There are some attorneys who practice both bankruptcy and family law.
